# Introduction
	
This chapter compares and contrasts the patterns of political behavior engaged in by military and civilian actors from the end of the American Civil War in 1865 to roughly 20 years later, in 1885. Using the case study method and through the use of process tracing, this chapter explores the "motives and opportunities" framework developed in chapter two of this dissertation.

The goals of this chapter are four fold: first, to argue that a decline in the military's prestige actually occurred over the period from 1865-1885, and to trace this decline; second, to argue that the decline in the level of military prestige over the period examined resulted in a reduction in the "opportunity" for both civilian and military leaders to involve the military in politics; three, to show that throughout the time period examined, the relatively constant yet high level of polarization provided military leaders with a "motive" to engage in political behaviors that involved the military institution; and four, to argue that the latter portion of the case study was altogether a less corrosive environment for the conduct of civil-military relations than the immediate years after the Civil War.  

This chapter proceeds in five parts. First, I explain what case studies are, and why they augment the research agenda already undertaken in this dissertation. In this section, I also defend the logic of the two broad case studies which comprise both this chapter as well as the next. Second, I describe the general predictions regarding the patterns of political behavior that should be evident based on the "motives and opportunity" framework previously set forth in this dissertation. 

The third and fourth parts of this chapter comprise the heart of the 1865 - 1885 case study. Each of these parts explores the earlier and latter parts of case itself. The fifth and final part of this chapter then evaluates and compares the differences in the patterns of political behaviors that occurred during these two eras. Using process tracing, I argue that the reduction in the military's prestige that occurred from 1865 - 1885 resulted in both civilian and military actors engaging in less public and less severe forms of political behavior involving the military. I conclude that the case study examined in this chapter fulfills most of the predictions made by the theory, but that it also differs from the theory in a couple of important ways. 

# Summary of Results Obtained, and How Case Studies Help
	
Before diving into the specific case study explored in this chapter, it is important to lay the logical groundwork for what to look for when conducting case studies, and to state why case studies matter in the first place. In order to do this well, I wish to briefly summarize the empirical results already obtained in the previous two chapters, as doing so will help motivate the specific case studies explored in the remainder of this dissertation. 
## A Summary of Results Already Obtained

Each of the two previous large-N chapters examined one form or type of a political behavior that is primarily (though not exclusively) engaged in by one type of civil-military actor. Chapter three examined opinion commentary authored by retired military officers and published in major newspapers, and chapter four examined the use of military figures in civilian presidential campaign advertisements. 

The statistical analysis undertaken in each of the previous chapters indicated that increasing levels of polarization drives retired military officers to author opinion commentary in ways that violate the principles of civil-military relations, and that increasing levels of military prestige drives civilian actors to use military figures in ways that violate the principles of civil-military relations. These initial results are important because they established a clear connection between each type of actor, military and civilian, and a particular form of political behavior that each engages in involving the military institution. 

Still, there is much of the theory that is not yet addressed by these previous results. In particular, the results have not clearly indicated whether and to what degree military actors are also sensitive to changes in the level of military prestige, as the theory predicts they would be. Additionally, because the previous chapters explored only one type of political behavior in depth, conclusions could not be reached concerning other forms of political behavior that each actor type can engage in. Historical case studies will instead attempt to examine an era, rather than one particular form of behavior, in order to establish overall patterns about the multiple political behaviors that occur in a given period of time. This is important because, as the US experience proves, the levels of polarization and military prestige vary over time. In terms of the five hypotheses developed in chapter two of this dissertation (and listed below), the two case studies undertaken in this and the next chapter will help shed light on all five, but in particular, H2, H4, and H5. 

H1: Military actors increasingly violate the central principles of civil-military relations when polarization is high relative to periods of low polarization. 

H2: Military actors increasingly violate the central principles of civil-military relations in public and visible ways when military prestige is high relative to periods of low military prestige. 

H3: Civilian actors increasingly violate the central principles of civil-military relations when military prestige is high relative to periods of low military prestige. 

H4: Military and civilian actors engage in relatively more visible and public forms of political behavior that involve the military institution when military prestige is high relative to periods of low military prestige. 

H5: The most extreme levels of overall political activity occur in environments that are characterized by simultaneously high levels of political polarization and military prestige.  

## Methodological Advantages Afforded by Case Studies

A case study, in the words of Brady and Collier (2010), "may be understood as a temporally and spatially bounded instance of a specified phenomenon" [@brady_rethinking_2010, 208]. These same authors define the concept of process-tracing as involving "the examination of 'diagnostic' pieces of evidence within a case that contribute to supporting or overturning alternative explanatory hypotheses" [@brady_rethinking_2010, 208]. Brady and Collier also argue that the use of process tracing within a case study is valuable for at least two main reasons.

The first advantage of process tracing through case studies is that it can inform whether the independent variables influence the dependent variable through the pathways, mechanisms, and sequences claimed to be at work in a given theory [@brady_rethinking_2010, 208-209]. In the context of this particular dissertation, this means that the use of case studies can help clarify the nature and the extent to which, in a given historical era, the level of political polarization serves as a "motive" for military actors to violate the central principles of civil-military relations, and the level of military prestige provides an "opportunity" for both civilian and military actors to do the same.  

This also means that case studies can help diagnose the degree to which endogeneity is a problem within a given theory. In this dissertation, this means the case studies should clearly illustrate that military and civilian actors engage in political behaviors that involve the military as a result of the level of the military's prestige and the level of political polarization. The case studies should not, in other words, demonstrate a relationship that works in the other direction.^[In the United States context in particular, the more likely problem with endogeneity, if there is one, exists between the independent variable of military prestige and the dependent variable of political behaviors involving the military, rather than with the relationship between polarization and the dependent variable. This is the case because as I have defined polarization in chapter two as the contestation of worldviews and moral judgments, and how they battle for primacy in the political sphere, any worldview differences are likely formed prior to the military's behavior. I recognize this may not be the case in other contexts outside of mature democracies.] 

A second advantage of process tracing within a case study is that its use enables the researcher to evaluate potential alternate explanations that may also be thought to influence the dependent variable [@brady_rethinking_2010, 208]. In this dissertation, this means that the use of process tracing within a case study can help inform the degree to which other explanations other than the levels of polarization and military prestige might drive the degree to which military and civilian actors are constrained by the central principles of civil-military relations. In the theory chapter of this dissertation, several potential alternate explanations were identified, including norm change and the prevailing conflict or threat environment. A good case study, therefore, should enable a meaningful comparison of these alternate explanations against the explanation offered by the theory.

For both of these reasons, the case study is an important analytical tool, both in general but also in this dissertation. While large-N statistical analyses (of the type undertaken in chapters 3 and 4 of this dissertation) and qualitative case studies may in fact, as Gerring (2011) describes, "explore the world in different ways," the two methods should not be viewed as "rival genres," but rather as complimentary methods that ultimately help "synthesize" each other [@gerring_case_2011]. 

## Case Selection Considerations

In this section, I describe the cases used in this and the next chapter, and defend the logic behind these choices. An ideal case study involves ample variation in one or both of the independent variables for the purposes of showing how the variation that occurs in one or more of the independent variables results in changes in the dependent variable. The ideal case study then allows for the researcher to argue that the reasons offered by the theory are responsible for the changes that occur in the dependent variable.

In this dissertation, the two independent variables of political polarization and military prestige always exist at some level. Additionally, these two independent variables change, but not necessarily in isolation from the other. That is, there is every reason to expect, and indeed, the empirical record demonstrates, that the levels of polarization and military prestige often both vary over the same time period, and sometimes in the same direction. When both variables change, especially in the same direction, it can be difficult to disentangle the relative influence of each variable. To the degree that it is possible, however, I want to find cases in which one variable clearly changes and the other variable either remains relatively constant, or at least changes relatively less than the other. In cases where such a pattern emerges, I can more easily discern the relative influences of the independent variables on the dependent variable.   

It is important to mention one other related but important consideration. Because the independent variables examined in this dissertation both change, I also want to try and limit the length of time comprising each case study, or at least define it as precisely as possible so as to limit the number of other changes occurring in the same time period that might also impact the dependent variable. In short, this dissertation needs to examine a relatively short and focused time period in which primarily one independent variable changes. 

Although United States history affords a number of potentially useful cases for this dissertation, a great place to begin is historical eras in which the independent variables hold extreme values. For instance, given polarization data that relies on Congressional roll call voting data, polarization levels are the highest in US history in two distinct eras, one ranging from approximately 1879-1912, and the other from 2004 - 2022. The same data reveals that polarization was lowest from approximately 1940 - 1970. 

The independent variable of military prestige is a little more difficult to gauge over time. Data on public trust in the US military dates back only to 1975 [@noauthor_confidence_2020]. However, there are a couple of historical signposts available that, in conjunction with other indicators that exist, such as the size and budget of the military, can help triangulate the relative levels of military prestige prevalent in a particular historical era. 

As a quick example, it is reasonable to conclude that the post-World War Two time period is one of high military prestige, given the scope of the victory achieved by US military forces and the size of the impact the victory wrought for the United States in terms of the role it went on to assume in the world. After World War Two, the size of the military sharply increased, and it assumed truly global responsibilities - something it has not cast off in the years since.  

## A Description of the Selected Cases

Given that the previous large-N statistical chapters focused on generally the contemporary modern United States (1979-2020 in chapter 3, and 2000 - 2016 in chapter 4), I am deliberately choosing cases that are mostly outside of this time period. I do so on the basis that exploring different time periods than those already examined will better inform the broad predictions made by the theory in this dissertation. 

The first case study I will conduct, and the focus of this particular chapter, is an examination of the roughly 16 years after the US Civil-War, from approximately 1865 - 1881. I will argue that over this period, polarization remained relatively high, while the relative prestige of the US military declined. Thus, this case study involves an examination of the political behaviors involving the military in a domestic environment that changes from one marked by high polarization and high military prestige, to one characterized by high polarization and lower military prestige. The main independent variable changing in this particular case study, then, is that of military prestige. The goal of this case study is to determine the degree to which the military's declining prestige resulted in less of an "opportunity" for both civilian and military actors to involve the military in politics. At the same time, the case study should show evidence that the enduring high polarization of this period nonetheless provided military actors with a "motive" to intervene in politics.  

The second case study, undertaken in the next chapter, is an examination of the period between the end of the Vietnam War and the Gulf War, from approximately 1973 - 1990. During this time period, military prestige remained relatively low, as the US military rebuilt in the wake of the Vietnam War. Moreover, the military had not yet achieved its 1991 battlefield victory in the Gulf War, an event which many in the military and civil-military relations scholars have come to view as a critical moment in terms of the military's rebirth after Vietnam. Over the same period, however, polarization rises, beginning in the mid-late 1970s. Thus, this case study involves an examination of a domestic environment that changes from relatively low military prestige and low polarization, to one marked by low military prestige and higher polarization. The goal of this case study is to determine the degree to which rising polarization strengthened the "motive" for the military to intervene in politics. Simultaneously, however, the case study should show evidence that because of the military's enduring low level of prestige, neither civilian nor military actors possessed a significant "opportunity" to involve the military in politics prior to the victory US forces achieved in the Gulf War.    

# Theoretical Predictions for the Post US Civil War Era, 1865-1881

## High Polarization and High Military Prestige

The levels of polarization and military prestige were both very high upon the end of the Civil War. According to the theory laid out in this dissertation, there should be evidence that due to the high level of polarization, there were significant ideological divisions within the military officer corps, reflecting the high level of polarization that existed in the nation at the time. Furthermore, there should be evidence that the high level of polarization prevalent at the time served as a "motive" for military officers to intervene in politics, and that military actors engaged in political behaviors based on these motives in ways that violated one or more of the central principles of civil-military relations. 

The level of military prestige was also relatively high at the beginning of this period, however. Thus, there should also be evidence that civilian and military actors engaged in behaviors that sought to harness the "opportunity" to involve the military in politics. These behaviors, according to the theory offered earlier in chapter two, should be relatively visible to the public as both sets of actors seek to leverage the prestige of the military. 

Finally, the theory predicts that the simultaneously high levels of polarization and prestige will result in civilian and military actors engaging in a comprehensive form of military politicization. This means that civilian and military political behavior should, together, reflect a rather extreme level of political activity, and that both actors will do so in ways that undermine one or more of the principles of civilian control, non-partisanship, and non-interference of the military.
