# Part 2 - The Army, Domestic Disturbance, and Failed Reform Efforts, 1877 - 1881

Johnson's impeachment and Grant's subsequent ascendance to the Presidency ensured that the Army would play a pivotal role in the political life of the American South during the Reconstruction period. Eventually, this role came to an end. when following the contested Presidential Election of 1876, President Grant pulled the last remaining federal troops from the south. This was the result of a deal struck between Republicans and Democrats that ultimately bestowed the White House to the Republican candidate, Rutherford B. Hayes, in exchange for the return of southern local rule free of federal military interference [@woodward_reunion_1991, 6-8; @marszalek_sherman_2007, 428; @wooster_united_2021, 242].

From 1877 - 1881, the regular Army encountered a number of difficult circumstances amid a tense and uncertain political environment. To begin with, the Army encountered significant friction as it looked for ways to institute a number of reforms to shape the institution for the next conflict [@clark_preparing_2017].^[Clark (2017) tells the full story of the Army's efforts to reform after the Civil War in his book, _Preparing for War: The Emergence of the Modern U.S. Army, 1815-1917_. See especially his fourth chapter on this point, "The Civil War's Legacy."] The 1870s and 1880s would proved to be difficult times for Army leaders to convince Congress and the nation that significant reforms were required, particularly in the absence of a compelling international threat.^[Grandstaff (1998) and Clark (2017) conclude argue that the late 1890s and early 1900s, after the Spanish-American War, is the period in which the Army became more successful at gaining support for their intended reforms. See @grandstaff_preserving_1998, 537 and @clark_preparing_2017 for more details.] A second difficult issue the Army faced after the Civil War involved apprehensions about its domestic role. The political tasks carried out by the Army during Reconstruction proved deeply unpopular with many Americans, and with southern Democrats in particular [@byler_civil-military_2006, 6-11]. Thus the Army had to navigate entrenched partisan forces that, in the wake of Reconstruction, sought to define the terms under which the Army could be and should be used domestically, especially during a number of domestic labor disputes in the late 1870s and early 1880s that involved federal military forces. Inherent in each of these difficult circumstances was the polarized nature of late 19th Century US politics altogether. Indeed, as the United States industrialized and its population expanded, it continued to wrestle with a number of significant political questions over issues such as immigration, the treatment of native Americans, and how to best continue to ensure civil freedoms to millions of former slaves in the southern United States [@azari_back_2016]. 

In this section of the chapter, I argue that in the midst of these still very difficult political circumstances, the military and its leaders did not pose as significant of a political influence as they had in the immediate years after the Civil War, from 1865-1868. As a result, civilian and military actors engaged in generally fewer and less public instances of political behaviors that challenged the principles of civilian control, non-partisanship, and non-interference of the military. 

I first set the scene by briefly showing that the level of polarization remained high during these years, from 1877-1881. I then trace the decline in the relative prestige of the military as an institution from 1868-1877. I make the point that this historical period in particular accorded with a decline in the prestige of the military as an institution, even while a number of individual military figures retained an outsized level of personal prestige on the basis of their martial exploits during the Civil War.   

I then narrate several significant events that involved the Army from 1877 - 1881, including the use of the Army in several domestic labor disputes and bureaucratic fights. I make the case that the general qualities of the political behaviors engaged in by civilian and military actors from 1877 - 1881 were noticeably different than those which both types of actors had engaged in from 1865 - 1868. In particular, civilians did not engage in the same intensity of efforts to harness or otherwise leverage the prestige of the military or its leaders for their own partisan advantage because the military offered a relatively smaller political advantage to civilian actors. This pattern in political behaviors prevailed, even as military leaders cared deeply about many of the issues at stake at the time, because they too were cognizant that they represented an institution which, at the time, carried diminished political clout. 

## High Level of Polarization, 1877-1885

The level of polarization remained quite high as Reconstruction ended. When we view Figure \@ref(fig:polar-chamber), we can see that after a couple of very small drops in the level of polarization in the US House, polarization only climbed beginning in the mid 1880s all the way until after the start of the 20th Century. Polarization in the Senate reflects a very similar trajectory. 

Scholars have noted that polarization in the 21st century shares more than just a couple of passing similarities with the polarization that prevailed in the late 19th century. These scholars make the point that in the late 19th issues related to "race, morality, immigration, and themes related to populism" contributed to American polarization at the time [@azari_back_2016, 93]. These themes remained salient as the United States emerged from Reconstruction and embarked on a process of significant industrialization throughout the decades of the late 19th Century [@skowronek_building_1982]. In short, the level of polarization remains relatively static across the entire period examined in this case study, from 1865 - 1881 (and beyond).

## Declining Military Prestige, 1868-1877 

However, the relative level of military prestige declined from 1868 - 1877. This decline was not the result of a single event, but rather the confluence of several trends that converged on the Army during the Reconstruction period and immediately afterward. These interrelated trends include the downsizing of the Army after the Civil War; the perception of many Americans of the Army as a result of its involvement in Reconstruction and the assumption of constabulary duties by military forces on the American frontier; and finally, the lack of an emergence of a clear international threat for military forces to prepare against. The combined effect of all these factors on the relationship between the Army and American society was that as an institution, it was not as central to the life of the nation, nor as respected, as it had been at the close of the Civil War.

When the Civil War ended, the Army downsized significantly, and it would continue to downsize for roughly a decade. Within half a year of the end of the Civil War, "800,000 of the 1 million men in the Union's Grand Army of the Republic were mustered out of federal service" [@laurie_role_1997, 21]. Four years later, by 1869, the Army's authorized end strength stood at 37,313 [Utley, 1974 and Cooper, 1986 as cited in @clark_preparing_2017, 99]. By the end of 1875, the Army was capped at 25,000 men, including officers and enlisted men [@laurie_role_1997, 21].^[Laurie and Cole (1997, p. 22) also note that only 2,105 officers remained in the Army after 1871 - a figure that did not change by more than 100 men until the close of the century.]

As it dwindled in numbers, the regular Army also had to contend with those who opposed reforming the Army. Many opponents of reform of the regular Army believed that the volunteer concept and individual state militias, on the whole, had served the nation well, and thus, that efforts to institute reforms for the regular Army were not required. Many of these opponents had at least a moderate degree of political traction because they had themselves served as volunteers in the Civil War, many achieving high rank and acclaim. This was perhaps most true of Senator John Logan, who in 1870 served as the House Military Affairs Chairman, and who had been passed over for command of the Army of the Tennessee by General William Sherman in 1864 [@clark_preparing_2017, 100]. 

The reforms sought by senior Army leaders would vary throughout the late 19th century, and would meet with varying degrees of success and failure. Early on, the intellectual question at stake between Sherman and opponents such as Logan was the degree to which military officers required special training and preparation in order to hone battlefield skills. Logan and others believed, based on their own experiences, that "the overwhelming determent of success as a commander was natural 'genius'," and thus they opposed the creation of the special professional military education programs Sherman and others sought [@clark_preparing_2017, 100].^[Key figures who advocated for reforms on behalf of the regular Army included, in addition to General Sherman, Colonel Emory Upton and Major General John M. Schofield. For excellent biographies of these three individuals, respectively, see @marszalek_sherman_2007; @connelly_john_2006; and @fitzpatrick_emory_2017.] Other significant questions about the Army during peacetime, including how the Army should man itself and against whom it should prepare to defend [@grandstaff_preserving_1998, 536-537]. The broader point is that in the early years after the Civil War, not everyone agreed on what purpose the Army served in the first place, and how to achieve that purpose in the absence of a clear international threat.

The Army's relationship with society in general also weakened as a result of its involvement in Reconstruction tasks and activities. Though it is difficult to precisely gauge the impact of Reconstruction on the military's relationship with society, we can reasonably ascertain that the Army was most disliked and distrusted by Southern Whites. To be clear, and as the front part of this case study made clear, there was significant variation in the way that individual military commanders in charge of federal forces exercised authorities over southern civilian governments. However, Byler (2006) notes that of particular concern was the way that federal forces had been used at or near voting locations during elections, particularly after 1870, when the military districts created by the Military Reconstruction Acts of 1867 ceased to formally function [@byler_civil-military_2006, 8]. The Army had also become increasingly scattered in a geographical sense. Laurie and Cole (1997) note, for instance, that upon the end of Reconstruction, "all of the cavalry forces and three fourths of the infantry" had moved to geographical outposts "west of the Mississippi Rive to battle hostile Indians and otherwise police the frontier" [@laurie_role_1997, 22]. For many Americans, the lengthened political involvement of the Army during Reconstruction, as well as its central role in instituting contentious policies against Native Americans, rendered the Army increasingly unpopular [@byler_civil-military_2006, 10]. Suspecting the impact of these developments on the Army's relationship with American society, Major General John Pope, while speaking to a gathering of Civil War Veterans in 1873, expressed concern that the Army might "properly and naturally become an object of suspicion and dislike" in the years to come [Cozzens, 2000 as cited in @byler_civil-military_2006, 1].

Like Pope, other Army leaders concluded by the mid-late 1870s that the Army occupied a less central position for the nation than it had previously occupied at the close of the Civil War. They did not like this development, nor accept it, but nonetheless, most of them, at the very minimum, were cognizant of it. For instance, General Sherman, in a private letter to his son in 1877, said, "our enemy is not now the Indians, but Congress...it is simply shameful that our pay and our Army organization should depend on the very men we whipped 12 years ago - Such however is the manner of a Representative Government" [Sherman, 1877 as cited in @marszalek_sherman_2007, 432]. Furthermore, Cooper (1980) notes that Major General O.O. Howard decried the fact that the public no longer praised and supported the Army, and lamented that "our people, little by little, have fallen back into the old ways of doing and thinking" [Howard, 1897 as cited in @cooper_army_1980, 31]. These sentiments are important because they reflect an acknowledgement by senior Army leaders that the institution was no longer operating from the same position it had occupied at the end of the Civil War. 

My argument is that this relative drop in the prestige of the military between 1868 and 1877 also impacted the form and quality of the political behaviors that civilian and military actors engaged in that involved the military between 1877 and 1881. Whereas President Johnson and his opponents in Congress regularly jockeyed for the favor of Grant and other senior military leaders and to portray the military's acquiescence to the public, civilian leaders from 1877 - 1881 rarely sought to harness the Army for their own partisan political advantages. Military leaders, on the other hand, when they did engage in political activities from 1877 - 1881, engaged in political behaviors that were far less visible and obvious than those that military leaders had engaged in from 1865 - 1868. 

## How Military Prestige Shaped Political Behaviors Involving the Military, 1877-1881

In this section, I narrate two related events or developments that occurred in the period from 1877 - 1881. I then describe the political behaviors that each actor type, military and civilian, undertook as these developments unfolded. Even as the level of polarization remained very high during this period, civilian actors did not attempt to harness the military and its leaders to the same degree that it had a decade earlier, and military leaders, cognizant that the role of the Army had changed significantly, shifted to engaging in political behaviors that were relatively covert and less visible to the public.

The first development was the use of the Army to quell what would end up becoming several domestic disturbances.^[Cooper (1980) and Laurie and Cole (1997) chronicle the use of the military in responding to these domestic incidents, which occurred from the late 1870s - 1890s. I do not address all of these particular instances in this chapter. See @cooper_army_1980 and @laurie_role_1997 for excellent and in-depth accounts of these events.] The first of these disturbances is generally referred to as _The Great Railway Strike of 1877_, which began in Maryland in July of that year before spreading to West Virginia, Pennsylvania, and ultimately, to Chicago. This and other subsequent strikes occurred as workers, particularly in the rail and coal industries, protested against what they perceived to be unfair and inequitable working conditions, to include the enaction of several wage cuts after the widespread economic downturn of 1873 [@cooper_army_1980, 43-45]. At first, state and local officials tried to respond to these strikes with local law enforcement and state National Guard units, but these proved woefully insufficient to handle the strikers, who had not only ceased all train traffic, but in some cases, had turned violent [@cooper_army_1980, 43-45; @laurie_role_1997, 30-32]. Despite having some initial hesitancy about involving the Army in what might be perceived as a "class war", President Hayes dispatched the Regular Army to maintain law and order [@laurie_role_1997, 32]. 

The timing of this strike intersected with an Army whose political position had been weakened in important ways. To begin with, Congress had failed to pass an appropriations bill funding the Army past July 1, meaning that the Army was essentially serving without pay. The failed appropriations bill, moreover, was a deliberate orchestration by southern Democrats against both the Army and Republicans for how the Army had been used throughout the Reconstruction era, and in particular, its use to secure polling sites during the contested Presidential Election of 1876 that had occurred just 8 months prior [@cooper_army_1980, 47-48; @laurie_role_1997, 31-32]. When Congressional Republicans failed to commit to any meaningful restrictions on the Army's use domestically after the contested elections, democrats "blocked the 1877 appropriations bill" [@clark_preparing_2017, 115].

The Army was generally successful in quelling the _Great Strike of 1877_, and many citizens and press outlets perceived the Army as such [@cooper_army_1980, 60-61; @laurie_role_1997, 52-55]. General Winfield Scott Hancock, who had commanded the Army's response in the East to this disturbance, likewise thought that the Army had performed well, stating in a private letter to his fellow General, John Schofield, that, "the troops have lost the government no prestige...it was the moral force of the United States government that was displayed - not its physical force" [Hancock, 1877 as cited in @cooper_army_1980, 61]. Yet even after this event in which the Army was perceived to have performed admirably, neither military nor civilian leaders engaged in visible political behaviors touting its success. The general political environment remained apathetic towards the Army. Not until 1894, when the next "great nationwide strike" occurred, did Congress allocate any additional funds for the purpose of dealing with domestic labor disputes [@laurie_role_1997].^[In 1894, the _Pullman Strike_ originated in the Pacific Northwest, in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho. See @laurie_role_1997, 163-178; @cooper_army_1980, 165-196 for more details.] 

The second development involves legislative provisions involving the Army undertaken by Congress the following year in 1878. Indeed, the army appropriations bill passed by Congress in 1878 undertook two important provisions. First, at the behest of Congressional Democrats, the bill instituted the _posse comitatus_ law. In response to what they perceived to be the heavy handed and inappropriate use of the Army throughout the Reconstruction period, Democrats "forbade the use of the Army as a posse to aid local officials in dealing with domestic turmoil without the express order of the President, and only then for very specific purposes" [@cooper_army_1980, 83]. Second, the 1878 army appropriations act established a bipartisan committee to examine "military organization and reform" [@clark_preparing_2017, 116]. The committee came to be known as the _Burnside Commission,_ chaired by Senator Ambrose Burnside, a former Union General, and would consider a number of important Army reforms, including its size, the number of officers, organization, promotion, retirement, and the commanding general's relationship to the Secretary of War.^[Fitzpatrick (2017) and Clark (2017) are among the contemporary historians who write about these reforms extensively. By the late 1870s, the combined team of General Sherman and Lieutenant Colonel (and later, Colonel) Emory Upton was well underway in laying the intellectual framework for a number of important ideas about the Army in peacetime, including how the Army might rapidly expand if a large war broke out. See also Connelly (2006).]

The Burnside proposal addressed Army reform from a number of perspectives, but it ultimately failed to pass. The proposal itself was somewhat of a compromise in that it recommended to maintain the overall size of the Army, while reducing the overall number of officers, including the number of generals [@fitzpatrick_emory_2017; @clark_preparing_2017, 118-121]. The Army did not receive the proposed legislation uniformly, either. Some leaders, such as Generals Sherman and Schofield, cautiously and perhaps reluctantly approved of the legislation, believing that it would provide the best chance for the Army to obtain any meaningful reforms at any point in the foreseeable future, while others, such as Sheridan, did not ultimately support the legislation [@clark_preparing_2017, 118-121]. Several historians explain the legislation's ultimate failure as reflective of the overall national sentiment at the time, which as Francis V. Greene would note nearly four decades later, was that, "this country [the US] would never be engaged in war; and therefore, in the midst of such pressing problems as the building of railroads, the resumption of specie payments, the silver question, and the tariff, there was no time to think about the needs of the Army. There was no 'military situation in the United States' worth thinking about [Greene, 1919 as cited in @fitzpatrick_emory_2017, 223]. 

What is especially important to note, however, is _how_ military and civilian actors engaged in political behaviors to support and/or defeat the proposed legislation, and what forms of political behaviors these actors undertook. Some military actors indeed did lobby on behalf of the proposed legislation, both in support of and in opposition to the bill. When they did, however, these military actors addressed primarily military audiences, and in some cases, politicians directly, and rarely addressed the general public (although there were some exceptions, which I note below). Other senior Army leaders also remained notably quiet altogether about the legislation, and did not engage in significant efforts either to ensure the bill's passage or its defeat. Furthermore, these political activities undertaken by military actors as a response to the Burnside reforms rarely, if ever, violated the principles of civil-military relations.

To begin with, a number of officers wrote letters to the Burnside Committee expressing their opinions on the proposed changes. For the most part, the letters these officers wrote constituted totally appropriate behavior in that the officers were responding to legitimate Congressional inquiry over topics that involved the military. Some officers went above and beyond the writing of letters in response to Congressmen, however.  Fitzpatrick (2006) notes, for instance, that some staff officers in Washington D.C., who in particular were concerned that the legislation would reduce their authority and influence by aligning the army staff bureaus under the commanding general, produced and distributed informational pamphlets to members of congress [@fitzpatrick_emory_2017, 221]. Senator Burnside himself, upon realizing that his legislation was stalling, noted, "I must say that some of these staff officers have gone beyond the line of duty, particularly...in Washington" [Burnside, 1878 as cited in @fitzpatrick_emory_2017, 221]. These behaviors can be viewed as acts of _shoulder tapping_ and _alliance building_ [@brooks_militaries_2009]. They also threatened the principle of non-partisanship, and perhaps to a lesser degree, the principle of civilian control. 

Military actors also engaged in a series of public appeals regarding the legislation, but these appeals were qualitatively distinct from those made during the period from 1865 - 1868. For instance, General Sherman passed on letters written by Generals Schofield, Sheridan, and Pope, as well as Lieutenant Colonel Upton, to the _Army and Navy Journal_ [@connelly_john_2006; 243]. Two things are worth noting about this. The first is that Sherman's behavior here should not be considered a leak per se, but rather an action undertaken with the author's concurrence and for the purposes of informing rather than influencing. The second thing to note is that the _Army and Navy Journal_ was a periodical intended primarily for consumption by military audiences. Sherman also made it clear, however, that though he thought the legislation contained more good than it did bad, he would not actively lobby on behalf of the bill [@connelly_john_2006; 243; @clark_preparing_2017, 118].
